terms.name: Elastic Clause
terms.definition: Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution allowing Congress to make laws 'necessary and proper' to execute its powers
terms.federalistPosition: Supported - believed it gave flexibility for strong federal government
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Opposed - believed in strict interpretation of Constitution
terms.significance: Central to debates about how much power the federal government should have

terms.name: Tariff
terms.definition: A tax on imported goods, used to protect American industries and raise revenue
terms.federalistPosition: Strongly supported - wanted to protect Northern manufacturing
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Generally opposed - hurt farmers who needed cheap imported goods
terms.significance: Major source of conflict between agricultural South and industrial North

terms.name: Democratic-Republicans
terms.definition: Political party led by Jefferson and Madison favoring states' rights, strict Constitution interpretation, and agricultural interests
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Their own party - championed individual liberty and limited federal power
terms.significance: Dominated politics after 1800, eventually became only major party

terms.name: Federalists
terms.definition: Political party led by Hamilton and Adams favoring strong central government, loose Constitution interpretation, and commercial interests
terms.federalistPosition: Their own party - believed in strong national government
terms.significance: Declined after War of 1812 and Hartford Convention

terms.name: Internal Taxes (Whiskey Tax)
terms.definition: Federal tax on whiskey (1791) that sparked the Whiskey Rebellion, testing federal authority
terms.federalistPosition: Supported - needed revenue and showed federal power
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Opposed - violated states' rights and hurt farmers
terms.significance: Demonstrated federal government could enforce laws, but created resentment

terms.name: Louisiana Purchase
terms.definition: 1803 purchase of Louisiana Territory from France for $15 million, doubling U.S. size
terms.federalistPosition: Opposed - Constitution didn't explicitly allow it, too much power for president
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Supported (despite Jefferson's doubts) - too good to pass up
terms.significance: Showed Jefferson compromising his principles for practical benefit

terms.name: Hartford Convention
terms.definition: 1814 meeting of New England Federalists to protest War of 1812 and propose constitutional amendments
terms.federalistPosition: Organized it - wanted to limit Democratic-Republican power
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Condemned it as unpatriotic during wartime
terms.significance: Destroyed Federalist Party's reputation and political power

terms.name: War of 1812
terms.definition: War between U.S. and Britain over impressment, trade restrictions, and British support of Native Americans
terms.federalistPosition: Strongly opposed - hurt New England trade
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Supported (War Hawks) - defend American honor and rights
terms.significance: Strengthened American nationalism despite mixed military results

terms.name: Embargo Act of 1807
terms.definition: Jefferson's law stopping all American exports to force Britain and France to respect U.S. neutrality
terms.federalistPosition: Strongly opposed - devastated New England economy
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Supported as 'peaceable coercion' alternative to war
terms.significance: Economic disaster that led to smuggling and eventually War of 1812

terms.name: Play-off System
terms.definition: Native American diplomatic strategy of playing European powers against each other to maintain independence
terms.federalistPosition: Saw Native Americans as obstacles to expansion
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Also saw them as obstacles, despite some sympathy
terms.significance: Collapsed when Britain stopped supporting Native Americans after War of 1812

terms.name: Impressment
terms.definition: British practice of forcing American sailors to serve in Royal Navy, major cause of War of 1812
terms.federalistPosition: Opposed but preferred negotiation over war
terms.significance: Around 6,000 Americans impressed; major cause of War of 1812

terms.name: Treaty of Ghent
terms.definition: 1814 treaty ending War of 1812 by restoring pre-war boundaries (status quo ante bellum)
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Celebrated as victory despite no territorial gains
terms.significance: Ended war before news reached New Orleans; improved U.S.-British relations

terms.name: Monroe Doctrine
terms.definition: 1823 declaration that Western Hemisphere was off-limits to new European colonization
terms.federalistPosition: Federalist Party effectively dead by this time
terms.significance: Bold foreign policy statement establishing U.S. sphere of influence

terms.name: American System
terms.definition: Henry Clay's plan for national economic development: national bank, protective tariffs, internal improvements
terms.democraticRepublicanPosition: Mixed - some supported (Clay), others opposed on constitutional grounds
terms.significance: Showed D-Rs adopting some Federalist economic ideas after 1815
